title: Fore Abbey Walk Route

images.title: Hugh Chevallier / Fore Abbey
images.caption: Fore Abbey. Originally founded by St Feichin in the seventh century, the building pictured here dates from the early part of the 13th century. It was a Benedictine priory and, at its height, might have had as many as 300 monks.

images.title: ÁineNicDháibhéid, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption:
This monastery is one of the "Seven Wonders of Fore" - 'the monastery built in a bog'. The other six wonders are:
The water the flows uphill. 
The mill without a race.  
The water that will not boil 
The tree that will not burn 
The anchorite in a stone 
The stone raised by St Fechin's prayers

images.title: Karant13, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Cloisters Fore Abbey

images.title: SE Keenan, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Fore Abbey exterior

description:
This circular walk visits the atmospheric ruins of a Benedictine Abbey, near Fore village in County Westmeath. The abbey buildings date back to the 13th century though it was originally founded in the 7th century. It was a Benedictine priory and, at its height, might have had as many as 300 monks.
The monastery is classed as one of the "Seven Wonders of Fore" as the 'monastery built in a bog'. Also of interest is the remains of the ancient church which was built around AD 900. The circular walk is called St Feichin's Way and runs for about 2.6km around the site and the village. It is named after St Feichin who founded the Christian monastery in the seventh century AD.  You can start the walk from the on site car park.
